abstract: An activist investor led the campaign against Home Depot’s management and strategy that culminated in the ouster of its chief executive.

lead_paragraph: For decades, activist shareholders were an entertaining, but largely ignored, Wall Street sideshow. Disgruntled investors would attend annual meetings to harangue executives, criticize strategies — and protest that their complaints were being ignored. One agitator appeared in face paint and a red nose after executives called him a clown.

headline.main: Gadflies Get Respect, and Not Just at Home Depot
headline.print_headline: Gadflies Get Respect, and Not Just at Home Depot

abstract: Everyone who knows him says it: In a tough fight, Kenneth G. Langone is a guy you want in your corner. But when Robert L. Nardelli, the former chief executive of Home Depot, refused to bend to the will of an exasperated board and accept a pay cut, he lost the crucial support of a friend who as lead director not only recruited him but presided over his compensation contract that would later draw so much fire, according to a report in The New York Times.

headline.main: How Langone Lost Faith in Nardelli

abstract: For decades, activist shareholders were an entertaining, but largely ignored, Wall Street sideshow. Today, however, it seems that activists have captured the center ring and are directing the main event. On Wednesday, shareholder advocates like Relational Investors‘ Ralph V. Whitworth could claim one of their biggest prizes yet when Home Depot announced the resignation of its chairman and chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, long a target of shareholders’ ire for his large compensation and the company’s flagging stock price.
